entry.title: Combined summary - Timed testing
entry.summary: A new testing mode for Bitcoin has been implemented and can be accessed on GitHub. This testing mode is useful for simulations like running nodes with different mining policies or detecting performance bottlenecks by testing as many transactions that can be processed. However, it does not serve for hardfork or double-spend attack simulations without calculating any PoW, which would be another interesting feature for a new testing mode.Jorge Timón, a Bitcoin developer, wants to implement the concept of private chains described in Freimarkets for hardfork or double-spend attack simulations without calculating any pow. He seeks feedback from Bitcoin developers on how invasive this would be to Bitcoin's source code. Running a private server involves various processes like listening to the p2p network for incoming transactions, validating them and organizing mempool, performing transaction selection, and relaying blocks to auditors. These processes are not tested in a reindex.In an email exchange between Jorge Timón and Gavin Andresen, they discussed the implementation of a new mode in Bitcoind. Timón suggested that the private mode only makes sense if it's useful enough for network attack simulations, which is still an open question. Andresen responded by proposing that the same effect could be achieved with -regtest by controlling node connectivity. In a thread on the Bitcoin Development mailing list, Gavin Andresen questioned the validity of using the -regtest mode in Bitcoin nodes to generate blocks after a few seconds. The discussion revolved around the potential implications of this approach, with some suggesting that it could lead to reduced security and increased vulnerability to attacks. Others argued that it could be useful for testing purposes, but only if done carefully and with appropriate safeguards in place.The author expressed gratitude for the explanations provided on using regtest to reproduce example scenarios. The author decides that a private mode would not be useful for testing and will work on private chains separately from bitcoind without creating a pull request. The author brings up Sipa's complaints about regtest being too specific and argues that some behaviors should be specified as independent parameters instead of chainparams attributes. In April 2014, Gavin Andresen inquired about the difference between running in -regtest mode and running in -timedtest mode, to which it was responded that there is no difference. The proposed -private mode could provide a way to simulate proof of work attacks and the author asked questions about simulating a pow race situation without actually doing any pow and measuring validation performance to get the number of peak tps that can be processed without taking block size or network latency into account.The author suggested one example of an independent parameter and proposed implementing the blocktime param as an independent parameter without the need for a new mode. The author welcomed any suggestions on how to improve PR 3824, especially from Sipa, as it is simple enough for the author to start contributing to bitcoind.
